 REPUBLIC OF SENEGAL PRIVATE SECTOR CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT Credit and Program Summary Borrower: Republic of Senegal Beneficiaries: The Government of Senegal and the private sector Amount: IDA Credit: 8 million (US$12.5 million equivalent) Terms: IDA Credit: Standard with 40-year maturity Program Obiectives The overall development objective of the proposed Private Sector Capacity Building project is to accelerate the growth of the private sector. To this end, the proposed project will help the Government of Senegal (GOS) complete the implementation of a three-pronged strategy aimed at enabling the private sector respond to the recent improvements in the policy environment. The two first elements of this strategy consisting of restoring and maintaining economic equilibria and removing policy constraints are being implemented in the context of the Policy Framework Paper for the period 1994-1997 and the Private Sector Adjustment and Competitiveness Credit. The third element of the GOS strategy, the implementation of which will be supported by the proposed credit, is aimed specifically at: (i) increasing the competitiveness and efficiency of private enterprises and business associations; (ii) deepening the policy reform process by analyzing remaining constraints to private sector activities and devising appropriate measures to eliminate them; (iii) improving the legal framework for private sector activities; (iv) accelerating the implementation of the government divestiture program; and (v) carrying out a program of communications and information to ensure that the main stakeholders in the economy understand and support the reform process. Project Description In support of these objectives, the project will help finance the implementation of three components: (i) a private sector capacity building component (US$6.3 million) to help private enterprises and business associations gain better access to business advisory services
 ii through a Private Sector Foundation established by representatives of the private sector associated with APDF, an affiliate of IFC; (ii) a policy and legal reform component (US$2.51 million) to assist a Competitiveness Review Group (CRG) and a Legal Reform Committee (LRC), composed of representatives of the private sector and of the GOS, in continuing to identify and propose concrete measures to alleviate policy and regulatory constraints to the development of the private sector and in strengthening the legal framework for private sector activities; and (iii) a component of specialized services (US$1.9 million) to help the GOS accelerate the transfer of public enterprises to the private sector and carry out a communications program to widen and consolidate national consensus on reforms needed to promote the development of the private sector. Project Benefits: The project's most important expected benefit is its contribution to promote Senegal's economic growth by improving enterprises performance and strengthening the private sector, notably through interventions in an estimated 600 firms over the life of the project. At the enterprise and business association level, it will: (i) increase efficiency and competitiveness; and (ii) most importantly improve management skill and raise awareness among private entrepreneurs that benefits from business advisory services might outweigh their cost. The project will also contribute to foster Senegal's economic growth by laying the ground for a sustainable supply response of the private sector which will be encouraged by: (i) a favorable policy, legal and institutional environemnt; (ii) an increased potential for expansion in particular through the implementatition of the government's divestiture program; and (iii) the creation through through public debates within the CRG and the LRC and through the communications program of a national consensus on the importance of a private sector development culture. Project Risks: The most important risk is the possibility that the GOS relaxes its adjustment efforts or back-tracks on reforms already implemented. This risk is very small, however, because these reforms have been initiated after an intense national debate and have now gained a wide constituency. The second risk lies with the Private Sector Foundation whose role will be to improve the access of the private sector to external support services. In the event that this institution becomes inefficient and unresponsive to the need of the private sector, an important objective of the project might be in jeopardy. This risk should be mitigated by the fact that its Managing Director, recruited from the private sector after a strict selection process, is highly qualified and that careful attention has been paid to the preparation of a detailed and precise Manual of Procedures that should reduce the potential for poor
 iii management practices. Finally, the private sector might prove to be unresponsive to the improvement of its policy environment and institutional support framework. This risk appears to be small in view of the substantial growth that has taken place since the devaluation in some sectors of the economy like manufacturing, fisheries and tourism. Environmental Risk: The proposed project which primarily aims at providing consultants services does not present the prospect of any environmental impact. It is therefore classified category C.

 I. THE MACROECONOMIC AND SECTORAL CONTEXT A. Background 1.01 Senegal is a Sahelian country with limited natural resources and a population of /.4 million in 1990. Social indicators, such as life expectancy, primary school enrollment rate and infant mortality, are at the lower end of the range recorded in Sub- Saharan Africa. Per capita GDP, which was estimated at US$730 in 1993, places Senegal at the level of middle-income countries. 1.02 Senegal's economic perfornance during its first 30 years of independence (1960-1991) has been disappointing. Population grew at 3% per annum, while GDP grew at only 2.5%. Senegal's agricultural base has been steadily deteriorating because of poor weather conditions and resource management. Industrial production grew at 4.5% per annum between 1960 and 1985, and at 4.1% between 1986 and 1991. Export performance during this period compared unfavorably with most other West African countries and averaged only 2.4% growth per annum. 1.03 Given the private sector's predominant position in the Senegalese economy and the poor performance of the public enterprise sector, sustainable economic growth in Senegal can only come from the growth of the private sector. This sector, which contributed about 87% of GDP in 1987, consists of a small modern or formal sector and an informal sector which together employ 90% of the work force. The dynamism of the informal sector attests to the potential for private sector growth given an adequate environment. In contrast with the vitality of the informnal sector, the formal private sector, which has operated since Senegal's independence with excessive protection from imports and restrictive market-sharing arrangements, has been characterized by decreasing productivity and competitive efficiency, high costs, and slow growth. B. Recent Macroeconomic Performance 1.04 In the late 1980s, economic growth, which had reached 4.3% per annum on average during the 1984-1988 period, deteriorated because of an overvalued exchange rate and postponed necessary adjustments. Since the beginning of the 1990s, the economy experienced a serious decline with a contraction of output in key sectors. In 1991, in particular, fish processing declined in volume terms by 66.4%; phosphates by 24.1%; textiles by 36.8%; and food processing by 45.8%. Groundnuts exports declined in value by 41% during the same year. Low economic activity resulted in a shrinking tax base which forced the government to reverse import tariff reduction and to increase the taxation of petroleum products. In 1992-1993, the economy declined even further as the difficulties of pursuing an adjustment strategy based on internal
 2 deflationary policies became more acute. The fiscal deficit and the balance of payment positions worsened; the fiscal balance (excluding grants) declined from a 0.2% surplus in 1991 to a 3.9% deficit in 1993. During the period 1988-1993, Senegal's economic growth stagnated at an average of 1.7% per annum. 1.05 In an attempt to reverse this economic deterioration, in August 1993 the Government of Senegal (GOS) adopted a series of internal adjustment measures including cuts in public sector wages. However, these measures were not sufficient to restore the competitiveness of the economy and its growth prospects. The extent of the appreciation of the real exchange rate, coupled with Government's inability to remove structural rigidities, made it more difficult for Senegal to restore competitiveness through internal adjustment alone. The decline in investments and exports, widespread smuggling and custom fraud, and increasing macroeconomic imbalances made inevitable the January 1994 devaluation of the CFAF. 1.06 With the devaluation, Senegal has now gained a unique opportunity to restore competitiveness and export-led growth, taking advantage of its strategic location and its sizable human resource base. Following an intense national debate which took place immediately after the devaluation, the GOS came to realize that this measure alone could not generate the indispensable supply-response of the private sector, particularly in terms of new investment and exports. Consequently, in early 1994 it outlined, and started to implement, a medium-term strategy for the development of the private sector. the key elements of which are: (i) a stable macro-economic environment; (ii) policy reforms favorable to sustained economic growth; and (iii) increased assistance to the private sector to help it expand and improve its competitiveness and expand its activities. The GOS's macro-economic objectives for the 1994-1997 period include a GDP growth rate increasing from the 2% achieved in 1994 to 4.5% in 1995, a return to low inflation after an initial adjustment in prices in response to the devaluation, with the inflation rate projected to decline from the 32% observed in 1994 to 8% in 1995 and 2.5% thereafter, a reduction of the current account deficit from 9.8% of GDP in 1994 to 7.3% in 1996, and a reduction of the budget deficit from the 5.7% of GDP reached in 1994 to 2.6% in 1995 and 2.4% 1996. In terms of policy reforms, the GOS has already implemented, in the context of a Private Sector Adjustment and Competitiveness credit supported by the Bank, most of the measures aimed at liberalizing prices and trade, eliminating rigidities in the labor code, liberalizing maritime transport and anticipates to improve, in 1995, the investment and export incentive systems. The third element of the GOS's strategy aims at encouraging the supply-response of the private sector by continuing to improve its environment, and facilitating the provision of business services to enhance the productivity and competitiveness of private enterprises, while resuming and accelerating the implementation of the Government's privatization program.
 3 C. The Role of the Private Sector in the Economy 1.07 Senegal's private sector is large, dynamic and constitutes the backbone of the economy that it dominates in terms of contribution to GDP, employment and investment. According to a 1994 Private Sector Assessment (Senegal -- Private Sector Assessment, The World Bank, June 1994), the share of the private sector in the country's GDP is estimated at about 82% and represents virtually 100% of the value added in the primary sector, about 80% in the secondary and 77% in the tertiary sectors. Informal activities, including those of the agricultural sector that are largely carried out by small farmers, are those which contribute the most to the country's economy. The informal sector absorbs about 90% of Senegal's employed labor force. In con.rast. the modern sector, accounts for only about 2% of total employment, the remainder representing employment in the public sector. 1.08 Tile Informal Sector. In Senegal, as in most African countries, the informal sector dominates economic activity in the primary and tertiary sectors, i.e. in agriculture, trade and transportation. Several factors have contributed to encourage the growth of the informal sector. In addition to repeated periods of droughts of the last decades which have accelerated rural exodus, employment opportunities in the modern sector were linited because of sluggishness in the economy and, most importantly, of persistent rigidities in labor regulations. As employers of the modem sector kept the number of their employees at a minimum, large numbers of unemployed people, including school and university graduates, had no other choice than to resort to informal activities. Complex regulations and government controls have also encouraged small businesses to remain informal. In the Dakar area alone, where unemployment reached 24% in 1991, there are about 30,000 informal micro-enterprises employing a total of 57,000 people as compared to the 38,000 that are employed in the modern sector. 1.09 The characteristics of informal businessmen attest to the existence of a class of entrepreneurs striving to make a living. According to the Private Sector Assessment, about 80% of all informal entrepreneurs financed the creation of their enterprise with their or their family's savings, and bank credit plays a verv minor role at any stage of operation of informal firms. Informal entrepreneurs are young, between 25 and 44 years old on average, and almost half of them (40%) come from rural areas. Despite the numerous difficulties that they face, informal enterprises appear to be resilient and about 50% of them have been in existence for five years or more. An increasing number of college graduates and educated people that cannot find a job in the formal sector have turned to informal activities and, as a result, about two-thirds of informal entrepreneurs are fluent in French, which is the official language. Nevertheless the majority (90%) of them need training in accounting, management, machinery operation and want to know better the administrative regulations related to their business. They also declared that they were prepared to contribute to the cost of such training.
 4 1. 10 The Modern Private Sector. Although employing a much smaller portion of Senegal's labor force, the modern private sector plays an important role in the economy. In 1987 it contributed about 26% of the countrv's GDP or about a third of the contribution of the whole private sector. Most of the enterprises of the sector are large, often with substantial foreign ownership, and operate generally in manufacturing, construction, trade, tourism and in insurance and banking. In 1988, the sector was estimated to include about 1,000 firms, of which 264 were in industry, 69 in construction and public works and 667 in services. 1.11 Private manufacturing is very concentrated. While a dozen fish processing enterprises compete on the export market, there are only two tomato paste canning factories, two flour mills, one sugar refinery, one factory producing edible oil, one major producer of milk products and one petrol refinery. Tourism, a potentially important sector in Senegal, has been reasonably successful in attracting private investors. In 1992, this activity contributed CFAF 42 billion to the balance of payments (equivalent to 10% of the country's total export receipts). 1.12 After the 1988 restructuring of the banking system, which resulted in the closure of several state-owned banks, the nine banks remaining in the system are largely private, with a substantial participation of foreign capital. The GOS holds up to 20% of the equity in only two of them. Three of the five major banks are controlled by French banks and a fourth by an American bank. With the exception of the Agricultural Development Bank (CNCAS), a first impact of the devaluation has been an improvement in the cash position of banks since most were creditors of foreign banks. 1.13 Public/Private Sector Interface. Since the Government initiated a divestiture program in 1987, 26 enterprises were privatized and 21 liquidated. Forty (40) enterprises are still Government-controlled. Of these only 13 have commercial or industrial activities. Public enterprises play an important role in strategic sectors and have a monopoly in water and power supply, in telecommunications and in processing and marketing of agricultural products such as rice, groundnuts and cotton. Since 1990-1991, the privatization process stalled partly because of deteriorating economic conditions marked by a continued recession and decreasing capacity utilization. Following the recent adjustment of the exchange rate, the GOS decided to resume its divestiture efforts as part of the reforms being implemented in the context of the 1994- 1997 Policy Framework Paper (PFP) and supported by the PSAC and the forthcoming Agriculture Sector Adjustment project. Presently 18 enterprises are earmarked for privatization --for six of them, privatization had been previously envisaged but not completed. Ongoing Bank supported operations include the restructuring and privatization of the water company, the strengthening of the railroad company and the privatization or liquidation of the airline company. The power company is expected to be restructured, and the role of the private sector in the energy sector redefined, in the context of an upcoming energy project for which the GOS has requested Bank's assistance.
 5 1.14 Since Senegal's independence, the modern private sector has been operating with substantial protection from imports and restrictive market-sharing arrangements. It has, therefore, never become very efficient. In contrast with the informal sector, it has exhibited less dynamism and has been characterized by decreasing productivity and competitive efficiency, worn out equipment, high labor and transaction costs, and relatively slow, if not negative, growth. II. THE ENVIRONMENT OF THE PRIVATE SECTOR A. The Policy and Regulatory Environment 2.01. Until recently, the policy and regulatory environment impaired the competitiveness and development of the private sector. In addition to an overvalued currency. Senegale ;e enterprises benefited from excessive protection through high import tariff duties. Some public as well as private enterprises were further protected by a system of prior authorizations to import competitive products, an arrangement resulting from special agreements (Conventions Speciales) that gave them a monopolistic position in the local market and substantial tax benefits. Following the January 1994 devaluation, and as condition of the PFP for the 1994-1997 period, the GOS committed itself to: (i) provide a stable macro-economic framework; and (ii) eliminate all constraints to the development of the private sector. In early 1994, it took m-easures to restore macro-economic equilibria by containing the fiscal deficit while reducing its internal and external arrears. Along with measures to contain inflation, it lowered imports tariff duties to a maximum of 45%, not including a 5% stamp duty. The GOS anticipates to curtail further the level of nominal protection, which is still high by international standards. This will be done in the context of the harmonization of the tariff structures of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU) member countries. The common tariff structure expected to be implemented by 1996 will include three tariff categories ranging from 5 to 30%. In late 1994 and early 1995, under the PSAC, the GOS took decisive steps to: (i) complete the liberalization of internal and external trade; (ii) improve exports and investments incentive regimes; (iii) liberalize maritime transport and reduce its cost; and (iv) eliminate rigidities in the labor market. As a result, only 11 prices remain administered, all special agreements have been terminated and all prior authorizations to import and export eliminated (except for imports of gold bars, silver bars and second hand clothes). Maritime transport has been liberalized while rigidities in the labor market have been significantly reduced through amendments to the Labor Code. The export and investments regimes are being reviewed with assistance from IFC's Foreign Investment Advisory Services (FIAS) with the objective of making them more supportive of private sector development. The review is expected to be completed during 1995.
 6 B. The Legal Environment of the Private Sector 2.02 Senegal has one of the most comprehensive legal systems in the region and has been a legal training center for neighboring countries. The Civil and Commercial Code, as well as the Corporate Law include the basic provisions on contract law and secured interests. The Bankruptcy Law is quite modem compared to legislation on similar matters in other countries of the region. It includes provisions for judicial settlement of claims and allows receivers to carry out recovery procedures under the control of a judge. However, there is a lack of alternative means to settle business disputes quickly. Representatives of the business community, as well as law practitioners, agree that the content of the laws relating to private sector activities is quite adequate, although some gaps -- such as the opening up of the legal framework to the informal sector -- and some updating, simplification and refining might be warranted. 2.03 Problems facing the legal environment for private sector activities relate more to the cumbersome institutional framework, and regulatory and administrative hurdles than to the content of the law itself. Entrepreneurs perceive that the legal and regulatory environment is unreliable, that the application of business laws is complex, and that it does not ensure the efficient settlement of disputes in accordance with the law. Lack of trained and competent legal practitioners to apply the law (judges, receivers, clerks etc..) is often mentioned as being the major cause of the ineffective functioning of the legal system. This is aggravated by poor working conditions, dramatic shortages of material and equipment and dilapidated physical infrastructure. Finally, erratic publication of the Journal Officiel (Gazette), virtual absence of law reports, lack of information on prevailing regulations and procedures contribute to reduce the transparency of the system and lead to inconsistent treatment of business operators by the judicial system. As a result, access to the courts is costly, lengthy delays are common and the uncertainty regarding the enforcement of judgments adds to the transaction costs associated with doing business in Senegal. C. The Institutional Support to Private Sector Activities 2.04 In addition to a supportive policy and regulatory environment and to an adequate legal system, the availability of appropriate support services is indispensable for a sustainable development of the private sector. In Senegal, the institutional framework supposed to provide these services is comprised of: (i) about 40 public and private institutions that were established to provide assistance to private entrepreneurs, to promote laws and regulations favoring their interests and facilitate their dealings with the administration; and (ii) close to two hundred consulting firms offering advisory services in all areas of business operations. 2.05 Government Institutions. The Government created a number of public institutions to foster private Senegalese investments and facilitate operations of existing
 7 enterprises. The most important of these are the Dakar Chamber of Commerce Clhambre de commerce de Dakar (CCD), the Societe nationale d'etudes et de promotion industrielle (SONEPI), the Societes des domaines industriels (SODIs) and the Sociegt d 'amnnagement de la zone franche industrielle (SAZFI). The role of the CCD, created during the colonial period, is to disseminate and explain the legislation applying to private enterprises and help private entrepreneurs overcome administrative hurdles. Although members of the CCD elect its Chairman, its employees are appointed by the Government ai.d act as civil servants rather than as efficient providers of business services. As a result, CCD is perceived as being another administrative outlet of the Government. 2.06 The three other institutions mentioned earlier were established in the 1970s. The role of SONEPI is essentially to promote the development of Small Scale Enterprises (SSEs) by assisting potential investors in preparing feasibility studies and in obtaining the required financing from the banking system. Despite substantial assistance received from various external donors, including the Bank, SONEPI has globally been ineffective. An assessment of its future role is presently underway and its privatization, if feasible, is envisaged. The SODIs are a network of institutions which administer industrial estates with a view to providing adequate infrastructure and facilities to new enterprises. The most important of these is SODIDA, the institution in charge of the Dakar industrial estate. SODIDA, which has succeeded in attracting 46 enteiprises is relatively well managed. Three other SODIs are in charge of smaller industrial estates in other parts of the country that house altogether 29 small-scale enterprises. Along with the decision to sell Government land to private entrepreneurs and to overhaul the land tenure laws, the GOS has recently decided to privatize the SODIs, starting with the SODIDA. The SAZFI was created to encourage the development of export-oriented enterprises. Enterprises established in the free trade zone benefit from total exemption from all direct and indirect taxes provided that they export more than 60% of their production. The zone also offers to prospective investors, land and adequate facilities and utilities. Despite a promising start, only 10 of the 32 enterprises whose application to operate in the zone was approved are still in business. Exports from the zone dwindled from about CFAF 5.5 billion in 1989 to about CFAF 3.3 billion in 1993 or a mere 1.5% of Senegal's total import. Three main reasons contributed to the relative failure of the SAZFI: (i) the enterprises' non- competitiveness due to the overvaluation of the CFAF; (ii) Government's denial, because of budgetary constraints, of some fiscal benefits initially granted under the zone regime; and (iii) the cumbersome and weak administration of the zone. In 1994, the GOS undertook to review, with the assistance of the FIAS, all existing export assistance schemes, including the free trade zone regime, to consolidate them into a unified and improved system. This new system is expected to be implemented in 1995. 2.07 Private Institutions. The most prominent of the private associations and trade unions is the Conseil national du patronat du Senegal (CNPS), a confederation of 14 associations of employers of the modem sector. The members of CNPS own about 600 enterprises employing about 75,000 workers. Two of the largest member organizations
 8 are the Conseil national des employeurs du Senegal (CNES) which represents about 130 enterprises owned by Senegalese entrepreneurs and the Syndicat Professionnel des Industries du Senegal (SPIDS) representing about 100 enterprises with foreign participation in their capital. Entrepreneurs of the informal sector have various associations, the most important of which is the Union Nationale des Commerfants et de l'Industrie du Senegal (UNACOIS) established by traders in 1988. Despite being relatively recent, this institution has about 25,000 members . 2.08 Recently created with Bank support, the Agence d'ex&ution de travaux d'interet public (AGETIP) has been very successful in helping small, formal and informal enterprises of the private sector. Operating principally in the building and public works sector, AGETIP is a private sector non-profit association, which sub-contracts small- scale and informal construction businesses to execute labor-intensive, municipal public works contracts. Since its creation in 1990, AGETIP has greatly increased the efficiency, timeliness and quality of municipal public works. It has also greatly expanded small contractor participation in public sector contracts and has demonstrated remarkable efficiency and tangible results. In its first three years, it channeled funds to 119 sub-projects generating about 11,000 jobs of 30 days duration, average. 2.09 Business Advisory Services. In Senegal, there are numerous private companies, including some local branches of large international consulting firms, that offer business advisory services to private entrepreneurs. A recent survey of private sector demand for business services (Etude sur la Demande/Fondation du Secteur Prive, Africaine d'Ingenierie pour le Developpement, September 1994) identified 100 firms, 15 individual consultants and 65 research institutes and training institutions that propose consulting and business services. However, the range of services that they offer is generally limited to project feasibility studies and accounting in the area of enterprise management, and to technical advice in agriculture, hydraulics and public works. The quality of their services is unequal and the survey found that, on the whole, the expertise of local consulting firms is weak in such areas as personnel management and marketing, and is virtually non-existent in production management, manufacturing and product quality. This is one of the reasons which explains that, according to the survey, few enterprises use their services and of the 64 consulting firms or individuals questioned, only 26 percent have had contracts with the private sector, the others preferring to compete for government contracts. 2. 10 The Private Sector Demand for Business Services. The recent elimination of protection, market distortions and the overvalued currency constitutes an opportunity for the private sector to develop and, at the same time, a threat for some existing enterprises. The private sector can now freely expand its activities in segments of the local market which were highly protected or in exports markets. However, some enterprises that were used to operating in a protected domestic market where considerations of competitiveness in quality and price were not relevant, will now have to face tough competition from imports or from more efficient local enterprises. The survey mentioned in the above paragraph was carried out during project preparation to
 9 assess the demand of the private sector for external assistance. This survey questioned 67 fom,al and informal enterprises, 12 business associations, all major employers' associations, all Chambres de commerce and Chambres des metiers, as well as 64 firns and individuals providing expert services. It revealed that although most of the private enterprises and associations surveyed felt that they needed assistance in technical services. less than 20 percent of them have had recourse to such assistance. The findings of the survey indicate more specifically that there is a strong demand from private enterpr-ses for expertise in such areas as production management, product and packaging design, quality control methods, equipment selection and maintenance methods, cost accounting and product pricing, market research, personnel management and project feasibility analysis. Private sector associations expressed an interest in obtaining expert assistance in setting up information services and data bases, in organizing training courses for their members, in improving their capacity to enlarge their membership or raise funds, and in creating and commercializing technical publications. 2.11 Despite the existence of numerous support institutions, under existing institutional arrangements many Senegalese entrepreneurs cannot receive appropriate technical and managerial advice to improve their operations. While the large firms that need technical services can have recourse to their overseas partners or parent companies, smaller enterprises are handicapped in their search for expert advice. The main reasons explaining this situation are: (i) inability of small entrepreneurs to properly identify their needs; (ii) lack of information about the services that are available; (iii) limited range of services available locally; and (iv) lack of financial resources or the difficulty to assess whether the gain resulting from external assistance will be commensurate with its cost. III. STRATEGY FOR PRIVATE SECTOR CAPACITY BUILDING 3.01 Government Strategy. Following the January 1994 devaluation of the CFAF, the GOS realized that sustainable economic growth could not be achieved without a significant development of the private sector. The GOS recognized also that, although the devaluation removed a key constraint to the expansion of private sector activities, this measure alone could not generate the indispensable supply response of the private sector. Immediately after the devaluation, it prepared therefore the three-pronged strategy for the development of the private sector mentioned earlier (para. 1.06), and described in a Letter of Sector Development Policy (Annex I) which served as a basis for the design of the Private Sector Adjustment and Competitiveness credit (PSAC). With regard to the first element of the strategy aimed at restoring macro-economic equilibrium for the period 1994-1997, except for external arrears (due to slower IDA disbursements than expected), the criteria and benchmarks agreed for 1994 with the Bank and the IMF in the context of the PFP have been respected. As indicated earlier (para. 2.01), in the context of the ongoing PSAC approved by the Bank in February
 to 1995, all monopolies previously granted to industrial or commercial enterprises, except for utilities, have been eliminated, internal trade and external trade as well as domestic prices liberalized and rigidities in labor code removed. The strengthening of the incentive systems for investment and export promotion is presently underway. The Government has now decided to implement the third element of its strategy aiming at pursuing the improvement of the policy and legal environment of the private enterprises and of strengthening institutional support to increase their competitiveness, both measures that are indispensable to ensure a sustainable development of the private sector. 3.02 To successfully implement this strategy, the GOS sought to ensure full participation of the private sector. A dialogue on the reforms needed to strengthen the sector supply-response to the change in CFAF parity was initiated in January 1994 during a seminar on enterprise competitiveness which was attended by representatives of the Government, the business community and the labor unions. Following this seminar, the GOS established two think-tanks to identify the key policy and legal constraints to private sector development and to propose solutions to eliminate them: the Groupe de Reflexion sur la Croissance et la Competivite (Competitiveness Review Group or CRG) and the Comite de Reforme Juridique (Legal Reform Committee or LRC). Both think-tanks are comprised of concerned government officials, representatives of private professional associations and labor unions. The CRG started to review, in February 1994, the policy and regulatory environment of the private sector. It has since participated to the design of the Government's reform program aiming at liberalizing prices and trade, eliminating rigidities in the labor market, liberalizing maritime transports, and improving the export and investment incentive regimes. In early 1994, the GOS created a Working Group to analyze the legal environment of the private sector. This group, assisted by a consultant financed by a Project Preparation Facility (PPF), issued a report in May 1994 that identified areas requiring substantial reforms. Since then, the Legal Reform Committee -- which has been operating informally since November 1994 and was formally established in February 1995-- has continued to prepare a program of reforms of the legal framework and follow-up on its implementation. Finally, to improve the institutional environment of the private sector, the GOS recruited consultants to prepare the creation of a Private Sector Foundation (PSF) the purpose of which is to help private enterprises and business associations get the support services that they need to improve their operations and competitiveness or efficiency. 3.03 Rationale for IDA's Involvement. Since the devaluation, the GOS, with the Bank's support. decided to resume its adjustment efforts. In support of this decision, in March 1994, the Bank's Board of Directors approved an Economic Recovery Credit to help improve the country's macro-economic equilibria and control inflation in the post devaluation period. This was followed by the PFP for the period 1994-1997 which presents the Government's macro-economic objectives as well as the strategy for the development of the private sector. The Bank initiated at the same time the preparation of a Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) and of the PSAC, both approved by the Board
 11 of Directors in February 1995. With a policy environment that has already been substantially improved, the proposed Capacity Building project will complement the Bank's support for the implementation of the Government's strategy towards the private sector by helping it pursue the reform of the policy and legal environment while strengthening the competitiveness of the private enterprises. It will therefore respond fully to the Bank's objective, spelled out in the Country Assistance Strategy, of helping Senegal achieve sustainable growth with equity and targeted poverty reduction. 3.04 Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Experience. In the past, the Bank undertook to provide assistance to the private sector through Industrial Development and Finance (IDF) type-projects, the latest being the Investment Promotion project approved in 1981. This project provided technical services to SONEPI, the Government agency described in para. 2.06 above to improve its delivery of support services to private entreprereurs and a line of credit to a now defunct development bank (SOFISEDIT) to finance private investments in the industrial sector. As shown in the Project Completion Report of this and other similar projects, these attempts failed bzcause: (i) the policy environment of the private sector was inadequate; (ii) the private sector was practically not involved in the project design; and (iii) the assistance to the private sector was delivered through a supply-driven process and by govermment institutions that proved to be weak, bureaucratic and inefficient. The proposed project draws, therefore, on this experience. First, the proposed project will take place in the context of a greatly reformed policy and regulatory environment where the exchange rate has been readjusted, monopolies have been abolished and price and trade totally liberalized. Second, all key stakeholders of the private sector have been fully involved in the preparation of the project. As mentioned earlier (para. 3.02), representatives of the private sector participated actively in all stages of the project preparation. Through the CRG and the LRC, they contributed to the design of policy and legal reforms that are indispensable to a sustainable development of the private sector. Third, the assistance to the private sector will be delivered on a demand-driven and cost sharing basis. It will be delivered by the PSF which is a private institution created with the collaboration of the private sector. 3.05 The project design also takes into account OED's findings regarding the Bank's previous technical assistance projects, as well as the recommendations of the Bank's report on Free Standing Technical Assistance for Institutional Development in Sub- Saharan Africa. The assistance and training to be provided by the PSF will be on-the- job and of a short-term nature. Local consultants' input will be sought whenever possible in order to minimize incremental costs and ensure an adequate transfer of skills and know-how. During project appraisal a series of ZOPP workshops (Zielorientierte Projekt-Planung or Project Planning by Objectives) were organized with the support of GTZ (Gesellschaft fiJr Technische Zusammenarbeit) for the CRG, the PSF and the LRC. These workshops, carried out with all stakeholders, assured broad ownership and resulted in the preparation of project implementation planning that will facilitate a precise and timely assessment of implementation results and allow the design of corrective measures whenever necessary.

Project Objectives 4.01 The overall development objective of the proposed Private Sector Capacity Building project is to help the private sector respond to the recent improvement in policy environment and to enable it to take advantage of new opportunities to expand. To achieve this goal the project will support the GOS strategy for the private sector described earlier (para. 3.01) that it has started to implement in the context of the PFP and the PSAC. The specific objectives of the proposed project are to: (i) increase the competitiveness and efficiency of private enterprises and business associations; (ii) deepen the policy reform process by analyzing constraints to private sector activities and devising appropriate measures to eliminate them; (iii) improve the legal framework for private sector activities; (iv) accelerate the implementation of the government divestiture program; and (v) carry out a program of communications and information to ensure that the main actors in the economy understand and support the reform process. ThLe Private Sector Capacity Building Component 4.03 The purpose of this component is to help private business associations and enterprises increas,. their competitiveness and efficiency through better access to business advisory services. Project preparation work revealed that none of the existing support institutions was capable of helping the private sector get the assistance it needs. While government controlled institutions were found to be bureaucratic and inefficient, private institutions lacked the organization and technical skills required to assist efficiently the private sector. It was, therefore, decided that the help envisaged in the proposed project would be better delivered by a Private Sector Foundation (PSF) to be created. The PSF will not, however, directly provide technical services to the private sector. It will act as a catalyst and intermediary between firms and institutions of the private sector that need assistance, and local and international suppliers capable of providing it. As reported earlier, to adequately design the role of the PSF, a survey was carried out during project preparation to assess the demand of the private sector for business services and the conditions under which these services could be efficiently delivered. Along with the findings reported in para. 2.10, the survey indicated that private entrepreneurs and institutions agreed that the assistance that they would get through the PSF should be: (i) demand-driven, with private institutions defining for themselves the type of service that they need; and (ii) delivered on a cost-sharing basis with the beneficiaries contributing to the cost of the services that they receive. The rationale for providing matching grants to private entrepreneurs is based on the fact that the private sector should not bear the full cost of external services needed to alleviate significant barriers to its development such as the relative infancy of entrepreneurship, market imperfections and externalities. This concept was used to provide Bank support to similar projects in India, Indonesia, Bolivia and Kenya for example. 4.04 The creation of the PSF was prepared by a Working Group composed of representatives of private sector institutions and enterprises that was formed in mid- 1994. Under the supervision of this Working Group, consultants financed by a Japanese grant to the GOS, were commissioned to prepare the PSF's Statutes, Bylaws and Manual of Procedures. Under the Statutes and Bylaws proposed by the consultants, the PSF will be a non-profit public service institution (Fondation d'Utilite Publique). The National Assembly of Senegal has adopted, during its March 1995
 14 session, a law introducing the possibility of establishing Foundations, a form of institution that did not exist legally until then. The Private Sector Foundation was created by 35 founding members, the list of which had been agreed upon during project appraisal. These founding members include representatives of private professional associations of the formal and informal sectors -- including, inter alias the Association Senegalaise des Femmes d'Affaires --, of the banking sector and of the African Project Development Facility, as well as individuals selected for their competence and experience in business. During appraisal, representatives of APDF, an affiliate of IFC, participated in the mission's work aimed at preparing the creation of the PSF. According to the PSF's statutes, its organization structure will be made of: (i) an 18 member Board of Administrators, the " Conseil de Fondation" appointed in May 1995 by the founding members during their first general assembly; and (ii) a Managing Director recruited from the private sector through a transparent and competitive process. The Board of Administrators has been formed and has confirmed the nomination of the Managing Director during its first meeting. The Board will meet at least twice a year to approve the PSF annual work programs and budget, assess progress achieved in their implementation, and review the PSF annual accounts and audits. The Managing Director will also appoint ten representatives of the private business community who will constitute a Consultative Committee. This Committee will convene at least every two or three months to review and advise the Managing Director on the PSF's operations. In addition to the bodies mentioned above, the Managing Director will be assisted by a permanent team of two high level professionals, an accountant and a secretary, all to be locally recruited. During negotiations, agreement was reached that these dispositions will all be implemented and that no change in the PSF's Statutes, Manual of Procedures and higher management will be made without IDA's prior approval (para.6.01(a)). The Manual details operating procedures governing all the steps from the identification of assistance needs of a would be beneficiary until the evaluation of the results of the assistance provided through the PSF. The Manual includes eligibility criteria for PSF's assistance as well as procedures for hiring consultants, supervising and evaluating the services that they would provide. During negotiations final agreement was reached on a cost-sharing formula, by which PSF's contribution will vary from 75% for consultants contracts under US$2,500 to 30% for contracts over US$20,000 (para. 6.01(b)). However, public enterprises and enterprises that employ more than 250 permanent workers will not be eligible for PSF's support. PSF will act only as an

With the Franc CFA parity change of January 11, 1994, the Government of Senegal initiated an overall adjustment of the economy to restore lasting macro- economic equilibria, sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction. This strategy is presented in the Policy Framework Paper (PFP), covering the period 1994-1997, prepared in June 1994 and approved in July 1994 by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. 2. Regarding the macro-economic objectives, the adjustment policy aims at achieving a rate of growth of real GDP of 4.5 to 5% per year starting in 1995, which will result in a per capita revenue growth of at least 2% yearly and the creation of 20,000 new jobs. This policy will also ensure the return of the inflation rate, as measured by the GDP deflator, to a low level of 2-3% per year after the unavoidable rise of inflation associated with the devaluation estimated at 35% in 1994 and 8% in 1995. Likewise, this policy will lead to a progressive reduction of the current deficit of the balance of payments (excluding grants) from 9.8% of the GDP in 1994 to 6.8% in 1997. 3. The Policy Framework Paper (PFP) that defines the macro-economic objectives for the period 1994-1997 is comprised of a set of measures aimed at ensuring the success of the new adjustment program. In addition to mitigating the social impact of the parity change and contributing to the application of a tight monetary and fiscal policy, the measures spelled out in the PFP aim at pursuing the liberalization of the economy, in particular, by introducing structural reforms needed to improve the functioning of the factor markets. Additionally, a public investment program -- based on the development of human resources as well as of infrastructure and on a prudent and sustainable management of natural resources -- will be implemented. 4. To ensure a sustainable economic recovery, a quick and significant increase of private sector activities is required. To achieve this objective, the Government prepared a strategy and an action plan that it will implement in the context of the Private Sector Adjustment and Competitiveness Program for which it requested the support of the World Bank.

The Government did eliminate the prior authorizations to import, except for certain agricultural products whose local production was threatened by external competition and for the products of enterprises benefiting from a special agreement or protocol for the reasons mentioned above in paragraph 13. 18. The import reference values and most of the import restrictions were eliminated in 1987 while import tariffs were lowered during the period 1986-1988, as envisaged in the previous adjustment programs mentioned above. Unfortunately, these reforms were followed by a sharp decline in some activities of the manufacturing sector and by a substantial fall in fiscal revenues. These unfavorable developments can be explained by the fact that other measures, including the devaluation of the CFAF, needed to improve the competitiveness of the enterprises had not been taken. In 1989, facing a dramatic deterioration of industrial output and employment and a critical drop in fiscal revenues that threatened the macro-economic equilibrium of the country, the Government decided to increase import tariffs and to reintroduce the import reference value system. 19. In order to profit from the devaluation and increase the competitiveness of the enterprises, the Government has now decided to liberalize foreign trade and put all enterprises currently benefiting from a special agreement or accord under the common incentive regime applicable to all enterprises. In particular, the Government will abolish all prior authorizations to import except for two products (gold and silver in bars and second-hand clothing). Consequently, seven4 out of the 18 prior authorizations to import that were still in effect were lifted in lune 1994. Prior authorization to import three other products (polypropylene bags, tomato paste and vegetable oil) has been abolished in October 1994. Prior authorization to import cement was lifted in November 1994. The authorization to import wheat flour will be abolished in November 1995. The time lag in liberalizing imports of the latter product is explained by the fact that the present special agreement with the milling enterprises stipulates that it can only be denounced after a one year advance notice. The time lag between the publication of the arreti and its effective application is explained by the need to avoid, in the second semester of 1994, a decrease in fiscal revenues that could be detrimental to the 1994 economic and financial prof ram. Finally, mechanismi to control the quality of imported products and to prevent fraud, under and over invoicing and dumping practices will be reinforced according to the provisions of the international agreements ratified by Senegal. In this context, an anti-dumping law based on GATT rules and disciplines was adopted in August 1994 by the National Assembly. The application decree of this law was adopted in nu 1225. This decree defines a process for applying antidumping measures that is fully compatible with GATT provisions. It indicates that: (i) consumers and importers will be represented in the commission that would investigate reported dumping; and, (ii) only temporary tariff surcharges established in full compliance with GATT and the with the agreements resulting from the Uruguay Round wil be applied to sanction dumping practices. However, the Government will not adopt a national legislation to enact the Uruguay round provisions concerning safeguards measures. In the event that the Govemment decides to use these provisions it will do in accordance with international agreements, in particular, with those relating to the GATT and the Uruguay Round. 22. Exprts. The Government is committed to stimulate and diversify Senegal's exports, in particular, in sectors such as fishing, agro-industries, horticulture, textile, services and tourism, and non-traditional exports in general. In the last three years, exports of goods and services (excluding factor services) represented only about 24- 25 % of GDP (as compared to 31% for imports). A particular effort will, therefore, be made to promote non-traditional exports. Besides the overvaluation of the CFA and the high cost of technical factors of production which have been now adequately addressed by the parity change, the development of exports is precluded by lengthy and costly bureaucratic procedures, the multiplicity of interlocutors, the cost of maritime transportation and the poor product-quality offered by Senegalese enterprises as compared to the quality standards required on international markets.. 23. The promotion of exports requires, first, the elimination of all barriers to the exercise of this activity. In this context, in June 1994, the Government abolished the remaining prior authorizations to export except for precious metals and minerals, and groundnut oil whose liberalization will be addressed in the context of the ASAP. Consequently, the remaining prior authorizations to export cereals, confectionery
 38 ANNEXI Page 8 of 12 peanuts, and jewelry were eliminated by decree in June 1994. The prior authorization to export tomato paste will has been eliminated in October 1994. 24. In addition, in order to reduce the cost of export activities and encourage their development, the Govemment adopted in June 1994: (i) an arrete authorizing exporters to import packaging material under the temporary import regime; and, (ii) a decree abolishing the levy of COSEC (the Conseil sln,6galais des chargeurs or shippers association) on exports and on the importation of inputs for the production of goods to be exported. Finally, the Government has adopted in October 1994 a decree simplifying export procedures and introducing new compatible with the international norm NS 06-001 which will greatly reduce delays and costs. 25. The status of competition in Senegal and the implementation results of the measures relating to trade and price liberalization will be annually reviewed in consultation with IDA. This review will aim at verifying that external trade enjoys a reasonable degree of competition with imports mostly in the sectors where there is a limited number of local producers. It will also aim at assessing the impact of all measures taken by the Government in these areas and ,in particular, of those which might have been taken in application of the antidumping law. More generally, this review will assess the impact of these measures on the liberalization of trade and prices and on the economy. C. Investment Promotion 26. Currently, there are several different investment incentive regimes in Senegal: the tax code, the investment code, the industrial domain regime, and the export processing regime (Free Trade and Single Factory Zone -- FTZ and SFZs). Despite the existence of these regimes which provide substantial fiscal advantages to potential investors, the level of new investments in the last years has been disappointing. The complexity of the different incentive regimes coupled with the long uncertainty generated by the exchange rate policy largely explain the weak performance of direct investments between 1986 and 1993. Indeed, during this period negative rates of foreign investment were recorded. The recent CFA devaluation will certainly improve substantially the profitability of investments made in Senegal. Nonetheless, an improvement in the incentive regimes is required to achieve a significant increase in the level of investment. 27. The improvement of the investment incentive system will concern, first, the export processing zone regime. Its fiscal incentives ought to be aligned on those granted in accordance to best international practice and the agreement procedures to the benefits of the FTZ or SFZ ought to be streamlined. As a second step, the Government has decided to rationalize the others incentive regimes that currently grant investment benefits only on an exceptional basis. The objective is to consolidate all existing incentives schemes into a unique common system applicable to all investors and whose application would be automatic, simple and prompt in order to build up the

The government is presently carrying out, with the Bank's assistance through FIAS, a comprehensive review of the export processing zone, the temporary import regime, the investment code and the industrial domain regime. The recommendatio is of this review expected to be completed by February 1995 will be discussed with IDA in April 1995 with a view to prepare action plans for their implementatior.. These plans will be implemented in 1995 in the context of the Private Sector Adjustment and Competitiveness credit. The aztion plan relating to the investment incentive regimes will be implemented in the context of the revised PFP for the period 1994-1997. 28. In the meantime, the Government has decided to adopt several measures to simplify and ease investment procedures and regulations. Firstly, it has reviewed the cost of creating new enterprises and adopted in December 1994 a law to reduce it. Secondly, in order to facilitate the dealings of enterprises with the government, a cunsus of enterprises and associations will be carried out in 1995 with a view to providing individual enterprises with a unique identification number that they will be able to use with any government body. Thirdly, in order to strengthen the enterprises capital base, the Government proposed to the National Assembly which approved them in July 1994: (i) a law allowing them to adjust their balance sheets to reflect the impact of the devaluation without increasing their tax liability; and, (ii) a law allowing the State to sell public land to industrial and commercial ventures. The application decrees of these two laws has been adopted in Januay 1991. D. Enterprise Comtetitiveness 29. The January 1994 devaluation and the enterprises continuous own internal adjustment efforts should result in a stronger and long lasting competitiveness position. The Government aims at consolidating these efforts by reducing the cost of utilities (facteurs techniques de production), the cost of maritime transportation as well as the cost of labor which constitute an important part of the enterprises cost of production.. 30. With respect to utilities, the Government will continue its policy measures adopted in the aftermath of the devaluation. Thus, in the context of the third and fourth water projects supported by the World Bank and other donors, the management of the Societ nationale des eaux (SONEES) will be privatized in order to increase SONEES productivity and control over its costs. With regard to energy costs, the Government has already requested the support of the World Bank for a comprehensive program to overhaul the energy sector. Before the end of February 1995, the Government will submit to the World Bank a report indicating its objectives, strategy and action plan that it intends to implement in the energy sector to: (i) eliminate inefficiencies and resulting rents and, therefore, reduce the cost of energy to enterprises and individual consumers; and, (ii) promote investments in the sector and facilitate their financing. This report will, in particular, include a definition of the role of the state and the private sector in the development of the sector and the streamlining of the

With regard to maritime transportation, the Government has decided to take measures to reduce its cost and simplify its procedures. To this end, the Government has abolished in June 1994 COSENAM's5 monopoly to exploit the national maritime traffic rights. In June 1994, the Government decided also to give to private exporters and importers the majority in the Board of Directors of COSEC, the shippers association in charge of administering Senegal's traffic rights. Through this decision, the Government want to ensure that the interests of the shippers are well represented in the allocation of maritime freight between eligible maritime carriers. In addition, in order to open maritime traffic to increased competition, the Government has decided to apply strictly UNCTAD's recommendations which limit Senegal's traffic rights to the maritime traffic, to be administered by COSEC, carried out by vessels operating regular lines under conference arrangements. This measures which has been adopted in Januar 1995, should result in greater competition and, therefore, in a decrease of the maritime transportation cost. 32. Finally the Government is intent on reducing the cost of the services offered by the port and the airport of Dakar. To this end, it has decided to reduce the cost and simplify the functioning, management and utilization of physical areas under customs supervision, by establishing a system of inviolable seals. This system will be introduced before the end of January 1991. In addition, in order to reduce the transit costs of imported and exported goods in the port and airport of Dakar (maintenance, transit, landing costs etc), a study will be carried out and its recommendations implemented in the first semester of 1995. 33. Labor cost and flexibility. Under previous structural adjustment programs supported by the World Bank, the Government had committed itself to introduce greater flexibility in the labor market and in the determination of the salary structure of the economy. Twice in the past, in 1987 and 1991, the Government prepared draft laws in accordance with commitments made in the context of SAL 11, HI and IV. The morosity of the labor market due to the weak performance of the economy coupled with the relative lack of information of the public opinion about the necessity of these measures, precluded the adoption by the National Assembly of a new labor law reflecting government commitments. This new law aimed at: "(i) eliminating the monopoly of the government bureau of labor over hiring, thus allowing enterprises to freety hire their workers; (ii) introducing more flexibility in the renewal of fixed-term contracts; (iii) allowing enterprise facing economic hardship to adjust their labor force; (iv) revising the salary structure in order to reduce labor cost and to give to the labor market a larger role in determining wages, reducing thereby the role of the State in 5 COSENAM: Compagnie sanigaialaise de navigation maritime

Although the draft law was not adopted, the Government acting by decrees managed to: (i) eliminate the bureau of labor monopoly and liberalize hiring by enterprises; (ii) authorize the renewal, over a five year period, of fixed-term contracts; (iii) amend the investrient code in order to exempt new companies from the rigidities of the labor coee; and (iv) extend the investment code more liberal dispositions concerning labor to enterprises operating in the export processing zone. 35. Despite these improvements, the Government considers that the flexibility and the productivity of the labor force should be strengthened as envisaged in the previous adjustment programs. Learning from previous experience, the Govemment has initiated a dialogue with tLe different social partners on the reform of labor practices. The Government also encouraged labor unions and business associations to achieve a consensus that would facilitate the adoption of the required amendments to the labor code. This dialogue resulted in the identification of two measures that the government has decided to implement. The Government, first, abolished in June 1994 the monopoly of BMOP' for hiring longshoremen whose remuneration was placed under the general provisions of the labor code which allows piece-work compensation. Secondly, the Government plans to authorize companies to freely adjust their labor force to the level of their economic activity. Discussions of this measure held at the national level -- in particular during the July 1994 National Partnership Forum -- have already established the basis of a consensus and this measure has been adopted in November 1994. In addition to creating an economic environment that is attractive to private initiative, the Government considers that it is important to improve of the legal and regulatory framework of the private sector and to increase enterprises productivity. The Government has requested and obtained the assistance of the World Bank to implement the necessary measures to achieve these objectives in the context of the Private Sector Competitiveness Technical Assistance Project. To identify judicial constraints affecting the private sector, the Government has established at the beginning of 1994, a working group including representatives of the government, private entrepreneurs and lawyers. This working group has identified, in a preliminary report submitted to the Government in March 1994, a first series of reforms to improve the judicial framework of the enterprises. These reforms relate to: (i) the provision to 6BMOP: Bureau de la main d oeuwvre du port.

A judicial reform group has since been established to prepare the implementation of these reforms. 37. The strengthening of the management capacity of the enterprises will complement the measures taken in the policy environment. To this end, the Government plans to create a Private Sector Foundation (PSF) that will play an intermediary role between the private Senegalese enterprises and the sources of foreign and local technical assistance. The PSF will have a status and a management similar to AGETIP. The Foundation will administer, on a grant matching basis, a technical assistance fund that would help enterprises to get the technical assistance that they need to increase their technical a and managerial capacity. 38. Operating in parallel in the context of the Private Sector Competitiveness Technical Assistance Project (PSCTAP), the PSF, the legal reform committee and the Competitiveness Review Group will, therefore, constitute the three components of this project. 39. These two operations, the PSAC and the PSCTAP, will both benefit of the financial and macroeconomic stabilization policy that the Government is pursuing. In the long term, the policies to improve the productivity of the production factors will contribute to maintain the competitiveness of the economy. This will be a necessary condition for the Senegalese enterprises to benefit as much as possible from the regional integration. In addition, competitiveness creates better conditions to reduce poverty, in particular, by job creation. Finally, it is a sure instrument for achieving the Government's growth objectives. Le Gouvernement du Senegal desire entreprendre un programme pluriannuel de communication avec le public Senegalais et les acteurs ou groupes d'acteurs economiques du pays. Ce programme est destine a rendre plus transparent le processus de preparation et de prise de decisions importantes pour l'economie et a renforcer la capacite du Gouvernement a faire connaitre ses objectifs et actions dans ce domaine. Pour cela le programme devra permettre d'informer et expliquer largement les mesures que le Gouvemement entreprend en faveur du developpement economique et social du pays et, en particulier, en faveur du developpement du secteur prive. Ce programme qui sera etabli pour deux ans, devra aussi apporter aux operateurs economiques les elements d'information necessaires a eclairer les decisions qu'ils comptent prendre et donc a rendre leurs actions plus efficaces et leur participation au developpement de l'economie en general plus efficiente. Pour atteindre ces objectifs, le programme devra comporter une identification precise des actions a prendre pour communiquer, pour chacun des themes qui seront juges importants par le Gouvernement, des messages dont le contenu et le support seront appropries pour vehiculer vers des cibles et/ou groupes de cibles precises les informations dont elles ont besoin. 3. doc.abstracts: The Private Sector Capacity Building Project will accelerate the growth of the private sector. To this end, the project will help the Government of Senegal (GOS) complete the implementation of the three-pronged strategy aimed at enabling the private sector to respond to the recent improvements in the policy environment. The two first elements strategy consisting of restoring and maintaining economic equilibria and removing policy constraints that are being implemented in the context of the Policy Framework Paper for the period 1994-1997 and the Private Sector Adjustment and Comprehensive Credit. The third element of the GOS strategy, the implementation of which will be supported by the credit, is aimed specifically at: (i) increasing the competitiveness and efficiency of private enterprises and business associations; (ii) deepening the policy reforms process by analyzing remaining constraints to private sector activities and devising appropriate measures to eliminate them; (iii) improving the legal framework for private sector activities; (iv) accelerating the implementation of the government divestiture program; and (v) carrying out a program of communications and information to ensure that the main stakeholders in the economy understand and support the reform process.
